results.content: Inspite of working as a front end developer for a couple of years now, I learnt a lot of tips and tricks to improve accessibility on websites. These are tiny things which I had never paid attention to earlier. Things are explained in a simple and easy to follow manner. This course is definitely worth the money.

results.content:
On the positive side, there is some excellent information. I've been pretty frustrated in that accessibility is often a short side trip put at the end of other courses, and being able to focus on the topic is pretty helpful. There was a bunch of information and advice given, which was good.

As a course, its a little lacking. There's no interactivity, no challenges. You aren't asked to apply any of the given techniques and instead it's more of a 2+ hour lecture on the given topic. Links were provided to the demo website, but I still don't know if my written notes and the lecture was enough to actually teach me anything.

response.content: Thank you so much for your detailed feedback, Vernon. I will try to do better.
response.content_html: Thank you so much for your detailed feedback, Vernon. I will try to do better.

results.content:
There were a few nuggets of useful information, but I found the content to be largely unstructured with little discussion about why accessible web/apps are necessary. The instructor seems to have plenty of knowledge but didn't create a course structure that can really benefit students. 
The use of examples were helpful, but the instructor bounced from one website to another without much consistency. We first begin with an animal hospital site with code examples and then we move to what looked like a portfolio site. It would have been benefical to focus on a single site to identify issues and remediate those. What was most concerning is when the instructor said not to use divs in one exercise, but she then used divs because she's "too lazy" to make them spans. Please don't use code that isn't correctly written. 
There was little discussion about WCAG and was brought up sporadically when the instructor was talking about a specific issue like Bypass Blocks.
Finally in Section 3: Making a real life website accessible, what would have been more useful is to provide students with a webpage with the source code to edit alongside the instructor. Instead students are presented with different parts of a webpage that can be made accessible, like hamburger menu and accessible emoji (low hanging fruit, IMO). Additionally there were videos that were unavailable to view and I was sure to submit that issue to the course instructor. Though it doesn't look like answers are provided in a timely manner according to other questions students posted.
Overall, I think there's potential to this course if some structure could be determined and if source code files could be provided to students to code alongside the instructor to walk through infusing accessiblity into a page, as well as showing how to use tools like aXe and manual testing techniques.
results.content_html:
There were a few nuggets of useful information, but I found the content to be largely unstructured with little discussion about why accessible web/apps are necessary. The instructor seems to have plenty of knowledge but didn't create a course structure that can really benefit students.
The use of examples were helpful, but the instructor bounced from one website to another without much consistency. We first begin with an animal hospital site with code examples and then we move to what looked like a portfolio site. It would have been benefical to focus on a single site to identify issues and remediate those. What was most concerning is when the instructor said not to use divs in one exercise, but she then used divs because she's "too lazy" to make them spans. Please don't use code that isn't correctly written.
There was little discussion about WCAG and was brought up sporadically when the instructor was talking about a specific issue like Bypass Blocks.
Finally in Section 3: Making a real life website accessible, what would have been more useful is to provide students with a webpage with the source code to edit alongside the instructor. Instead students are presented with different parts of a webpage that can be made accessible, like hamburger menu and accessible emoji (low hanging fruit, IMO). Additionally there were videos that were unavailable to view and I was sure to submit that issue to the course instructor. Though it doesn't look like answers are provided in a timely manner according to other questions students posted.
Overall, I think there's potential to this course if some structure could be determined and if source code files could be provided to students to code alongside the instructor to walk through infusing accessiblity into a page, as well as showing how to use tools like aXe and manual testing techniques.

results.content:
There was certainly a lot of helpful information and insight in the course! The tone was sometimes a bit demeaning though, as people taking this course in theory don't know anything about accessibility, but the instructor made some statements like "a lot of developers do this for absolutely no reason and it makes no sense because it's so so bad for accessibility." Well, the developers probably did have some reasons, and maybe some course participants have done this too, and we are now trying to be better! Just show what is right and what is wrong, no need to be insulting about it and attack others. 

Also several points and even examples were repetitive in different videos, which was unnecessary. Volume levels also changed between videos...felt a bit jarring to watch some times.

Overall decent content though and helpful for someone just starting out with accessibility.

response.content:
I am very sorry about that. If you can PM me which video is it that I say these stuff, I will make sure to cut the audio or edit it in some way. 
Again, terribly sorry.
response.content_html:
I am very sorry about that. If you can PM me which video is it that I say these stuff, I will make sure to cut the audio or edit it in some way.
Again, terribly sorry.

results.content_html:
There was certainly a lot of helpful information and insight in the course! The tone was sometimes a bit demeaning though, as people taking this course in theory don't know anything about accessibility, but the instructor made some statements like "a lot of developers do this for absolutely no reason and it makes no sense because it's so so bad for accessibility." Well, the developers probably did have some reasons, and maybe some course participants have done this too, and we are now trying to be better! Just show what is right and what is wrong, no need to be insulting about it and attack others.

Also several points and even examples were repetitive in different videos, which was unnecessary. Volume levels also changed between videos...felt a bit jarring to watch some times.

Overall decent content though and helpful for someone just starting out with accessibility.

 Your voice is nice, so slow down, please.

results.content:
I learned a few things about accessibility and I like that course was practical with many examples. However few things I think could/should be improved :)

* there's a lot of comments about how a screen reader would read it - instead I would prefer to hear it myself. It would require some video editing and more work, but course would be a lot more practical.
* implementing a hamburger lesson - it's a rather a CSS lesson, code could be already there, author could spend some time explaining how it works and then explain it from accessibility point of view.
* same as above for an "accessible javascript part 3" - the lesson is too long to begin with, and it's 90% javascript lesson and 10% accessibility. Again I think code could be pasted or video-edited while author would explain accessibility concepts. It can be 20 min lesson at most.
* there were some inconsistencies like author telling viewers not to use id's for styling but at the same time doing it, or telling you should never use a "title" attribute in one lesson then on the next one saying you should use it for iframes.
results.content_html:
I learned a few things about accessibility and I like that course was practical with many examples. However few things I think could/should be improved :)

* there's a lot of comments about how a screen reader would read it - instead I would prefer to hear it myself. It would require some video editing and more work, but course would be a lot more practical.
* implementing a hamburger lesson - it's a rather a CSS lesson, code could be already there, author could spend some time explaining how it works and then explain it from accessibility point of view.
* same as above for an "accessible javascript part 3" - the lesson is too long to begin with, and it's 90% javascript lesson and 10% accessibility. Again I think code could be pasted or video-edited while author would explain accessibility concepts. It can be 20 min lesson at most.
* there were some inconsistencies like author telling viewers not to use id's for styling but at the same time doing it, or telling you should never use a "title" attribute in one lesson then on the next one saying you should use it for iframes.

results.content:
I like that the teacher was showing practically what she was talking about. 
Even though (or maybe because) she has an accent, it was much more easy to follow her than a native English speaker. 
Sometimes, the lectures could be more systematically pieced together. But it was good :)

response.content:
Hi Ludmila,

Thank you for your feedback. I am so happy you liked the course and my accent wasn't an issue, hehe. In case it is, the course has captions done by a professional.
I will try to make the lectures more pieced together, thank you!
response.content_html:
Hi Ludmila,

Thank you for your feedback. I am so happy you liked the course and my accent wasn't an issue, hehe. In case it is, the course has captions done by a professional.
I will try to make the lectures more pieced together, thank you!

results.content_html:
I like that the teacher was showing practically what she was talking about.
Even though (or maybe because) she has an accent, it was much more easy to follow her than a native English speaker.
Sometimes, the lectures could be more systematically pieced together. But it was good :)

results.content: Very nice instructor!!! All the information was helpful in rethinking how we need to make sites accessible to all users.
results.content_html: Very nice instructor!!! All the information was helpful in rethinking how we need to make sites accessible to all users.

results.content:
The transition from overview to instruction was a bit rough.
I do not actually have quite enough CSS experience for this course, but I'm getting it because the instructor is explaining things really well. Good work!
results.content_html:

results.content: The content is good. The instructor needs to stop using slang as it comes across as very unprofessional. This is the first online course I've taken where the instructor actually said "b******t." She said "douchebaggy" in another course in describing the same issue -- content writers using big words. "Stupid" is another word that pops up frequently. Please stop. I'd rather deal with a big vocabulary than a little one.

This is the first online course I've taken where the instructor actually said "b******t." She said "douchebaggy" in another course in describing the same issue -- content writers using big words. "Stupid" is another word that pops up frequently. Please stop. I'd rather deal with a big vocabulary than a little one.

results.content: Great course . Definitely helps understanding the foundation of accessible websites
results.content_html: Great course . Definitely helps understanding the foundation of accessible websites

results.content: Course is really useful. Presenter gives practical examples all the time, which makes for an easy understanding. The missing half star is due to the video editing, which can be improved, but overall I would definately recommend it to everybody dealing with front-end development.

response.content: Thank you very much for taking the time to leave a detailed feedback. I am happy you liked the course! I will try to fix the editing issues as soon as possible.
response.content_html: Thank you very much for taking the time to leave a detailed feedback. I am happy you liked the course! I will try to fix the editing issues as soon as possible.

The missing half star is due to the video editing, which can be improved, but overall I would definately recommend it to everybody dealing with front-end development.

results.content: Super interesting little course - great insights. Video editing could be better so it is easier to follow and some content is slightly repeated/a little out of sync.
